School of Resources and Environmental Sciences Wuhan University Wuhan 430079 PR China Graphical abstract Efficient ammonia synthesis is a significant but challenging target. Herein, the perovskite Ba5Ta4O15 nanosheets were prepared as a support to rationally construct Cs modified Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 (Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15) for this end. The Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 catalyst exhibits high catalytic activity and stability in 72 h ammonia synthesis reaction process at 400 ℃ and 0.1 MPa. Characterizations by various physicochemical techniques reveal that Ba5Ta4O15 can be reduced, resulting in formation of oxygen vacancies (OVs) under reaction conditions. The presence of OVs in Ba5Ta4O15 significantly enhances the ammonia synthesis of the Ru based catalyst. The activation of N2 and formation of NH3 can be realized on Ba5Ta4O15 with OVs even without Ru metals. Moreover, the kinetic experiments indicate that hydrogen poisoning is greatly inhibited through promotion of hydrogen spillover from Ru to support of Ba5Ta4O15. Therefore, Ba5Ta4O15 is expected to be a promising support of Ru based ammonia synthesis catalysts. Keywords Ba5Ta4O15 Ammonia synthesis Ru catalysts Cs-promotion Oxygen vacancies 1 Introduction Ammonia is a bulk chemical widely used in the production of fertilizers, plastics and fibers [1]. Recently, ammonia is considered as the hydrogen carrier to realize hydrogen economy [2]. It is industrially produced by Haber-Bosch process catalyzed with fused iron. However, Haber-Bosch process operates at high temperatures (400–600 ℃) and high pressures (15−25 MPa) [3]. It consumes a great deal of energy accounting for about 1% of the global energy consumption [4]. Therefore, a more energy-efficient ammonia synthesis process operated at milder conditions is strongly needed for future hydrogen society. Ru catalysts, as the second-generation ammonia catalyst, have been widely studied for their promising catalytic activity at low temperature and pressure. So far, various materials have been investigated as supports for Ru crystallites such as carbon [5–7], MgO [8–11], Al2O3 [12–15], CeO2 [16,17], zeolite [18,19], 12CaO7 Al2O3:e− (C12A7:e−) [20], Pr2O3 [21], [Ca2N]:e− [22], CaH2 and Ca2NH [23,24]. Since 1992, Ru/carbon catalysts have been industrially used in the KBR advanced ammonia process (KAAP). However, for ammonia synthesis, the carbon carriers and H2 are prone to react to form methane in the presence of Ru catalysts. The instability of the carbon support limits the lifetime of the Ru/carbon catalysts [25]. Moreover, Ru/MgO is prone to hydrogen poisoning under high hydrogen partial pressure and lacks textural stability [26,27], preventing its potential wide application in industry. Therefore, development of new supports to construct Ru based catalytic ammonia synthesis systems with high performance and high stability is still a significant but challenging target. Perovskite oxides possess the general formula of ABO3, wherein large cations occupy the A- site and have 12 coordination positions for oxygen atoms, while small cations occupy the b-site with 6 coordination sites. A- and B-sites in perovskite can be tailored by substituting with other foreign cations with different sizes and charges to tune its crystallite structure and properties. Nonstoichiometry (e.g., oxygen deficiencies) in perovskites has been also widely discussed in catalytic applications [28]. Perovskite-type oxides have been used as a carrier for Ru catalysts to enhance ammonia synthesis such as BaZrO3, BaTiO3 and Sr2Nb2O7 [29–31]. In these perovskites, oxygen vacancies (OVs) and the related low valent metal species can be easily formed under ammonia synthesis conditions. Particularly, some documents reported that OVs could play a key role in the catalytic activation of N2 in enhanced photocatalytic synthesis of ammonia by BiOBr and BiOCl nanosheets [32,33]. However, the role of OVs and the related low valent metal species in perovskite substrates in thermal catalytic synthesis of ammonia has been seldom systematically investigated. In this work, the perovskite-type Ba5Ta4O15 was synthesized by hydrothermal method and tested as a model carrier of perovskite substrates for promoting synthesis of ammonia by particulate Ru. The reasons for choosing Ba5Ta4O15 as a support are as follows: First, oxygen vacancies (OVs) and the related low valent Ta species in Ba5Ta4O15 can be easily generated under the reaction conditions of ammonia synthesis, and the amount of OVs in Ba5Ta4O15 can be tuned finely. Therefore, the role of OVs and the related low valent Ta species in perovskite Ba5Ta4O15 in the dissociation of N2 molecules and production of ammonia by supported Ru particles can be systematically investigated. Secondly, Ba5Ta4O15 nanaosheets structure facilitates the epitaxial growth of flat Ru crystallites on its layers, which can further promotes the catalytic activity of Ru crystallites because of the exposure of rich B5 sites on the surface of flat Ru crystallites [34,35]. Based on the consideration above, a new catalytic system for ammonia synthesis was constructed with Ba5Ta4O15 nanosheets as a carrier of Ru catalysts and Cs as a promoter. The ternary Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 system exhibited superior catalytic activity and stability for ammonia synthesis. The mechanism for enhancement role of OVs in Ba5Ta4O15 nanosheets for ammonia synthesis in the novel Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 system was clarified. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The Ba5Ta4O15 support was prepared through a hydrothermal process [36]. All reagents are analytical grade and used without further purification. Typically, 6.300 g Ba(OH)2·8H2O (20.0 mmol) and 0.550 g Ta2O5 (1.25 mmol) were added into 45 mL of pure water and stirred for 60 min. Then, a Teflon-lined autoclave (100 mL) was used to hold this mixture and treated at 200 ℃ for 7 days. The white product was recycled through filtration and washed repeatedly with pure water until the pH of the filtrate was close to neutral. Finally the sample was dried at 60 ℃ in an oven for 12 h. Ru catalysts were synthesized by impregnation method [37]. A certain amount of Ru3(CO)12 was dissolved in tetrahydrofuran solution, and then Ba5Ta4O15 support was added. The mixture was stirred at 25 ℃ for 5 h. Afterwards, a rotary evaporator was used to remove the tetrahydrofuran solvent at 40 ℃ and 10 K Pa. The obtained powder was decomposed at 250 ℃ for 3 h under an Ar flow (99.999 %, 5 mL min−1). To prepare Cs-promoted catalysts, the resulting Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 catalyst was mixed with nitrate promoter (CsNO3) at a Cs to Ru molar ratio of 1, 2, 3 and 4 in a mortar and physically ground for 30 min until the mixture was uniform. Accordingly, the produced catalysts were named as 1Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15, 2Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15, 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 and 4Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15. After pelletization, crushing and sieving treatment, the as-prepared samples with particle size in the range of 220–450 μm were collected for use. The Cs-Ru/MgO catalyst was prepared by using the same method. Commercial product MgO was calcined at 500 ℃ for 5 h before use. 2.2 Catalyst characterizations Crystalline structure analysis was conducted using a powder x-ray diffraction (XRD, PANalytical X’Pert Pro) technique with a Cu-Kα radiation source (λ =1.5405 Å) in a 2θ range from 10°-80° with a scan speed of 5° min−1. The oxygen vacancies were detected at room temperature on an electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectrometer (Bruker, EMXnano). X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were analyzed on an ESCALAB 250Xi (Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc., USA). The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area was evaluated by N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm on BELSORPmini II (BEL, Japan) at -196 ℃. Before analysis, all catalysts were degassed at 200 ℃ and 10−2 KPa for 2 h. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Zeiss Sigma) was used to observe the morphology of Ba5Ta4O15 sample with an acceleration voltage of 5 kV. Transmission electron microscope (TEM, JEM-2100, JEOL, Japan) was used to recorded the microstructures of Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 with an acceleration voltage of 200 kV. The Ru loading of the catalysts was detected by ICP-AES (IRIS Intrepid II XSP, Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc., USA). Appropriate amount of catalyst was treated in 6 mL HCl (36 %) and 2 mL HNO3 (68 %) in a Teflon-lined autoclave (100 mL) at 150 °C for 5 h. The hydrothermally dissolved Ru solution was diluted with pure water prior to ICP measurements. Temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiments were recorded on an Altamira AMI-300 instrument with a thermal conductivity detector. Prior to test, the samples (0.100 g) were pretreated in Ar (30 mL min−1) at 400 °C for 1 h. After cooling down to 25 °C, the catalyst was purged in a flow of Ar (30 mL min−1). Then the temperature was raised up to 800 °C at 10 °C min−1 in 30 mL min−1 of 10 vol% H2/Ar and maintained 30 min. Temperature programmed desorption (TPD) measurements were carried out on the same apparatus. Before test, the catalyst (0.100 g) was reduced by H2/Ar (1: 9, v/v; 30 mL min−1 total flow) at 400 ℃ for 3 h, and purged in flow of He (30 mL min−1) at 400 ℃ for 1 h to remove H2. After being cooled to room temperature in He, the sample adsorbed NH3 for 1 h at 50 ℃, and then flushed in He for 30 min. Finally, the temperature was increased linearly from 50 ℃ to 900 ℃ at 10 ℃ min−1 using He as carrier gas, and then maintain 30 min. But Ba5Ta4O15 was pretreated by He (30 mL min−1 total flow) at 400 ℃ for 3 h. The in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectra (DRIFTS) of adsorbed N2 were collected in an integration system composed of a high-temperature reaction chamber (HVC, Harrick Scientific Products Inc., USA) and a Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectrometer (Nicolet IS50, Thermo Fisher, USA) with a MCT (HgCdTe) detector. Prior to tests, the samples were pretreated in 45 mL min−1 of H2 or Ar at 400 ℃ for 3 h, and then purged at the same temperature for 30 min with Ar flow (15 mL min−1). After the samples were cooled down to 25 ℃ in 15 mL min−1 Ar flow, the background spectra were collected. Further, the samples were exposed to 15 mL min−1 of N2 and the FTIR spectra for N2 adsorbed on the catalyst were recorded. All spectra were collected repeatedly for 32 times in the wavenumber range of 800–4200 cm−1 with 4 cm−1 resolution. 2.3 Activity measurements The activity of the Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 catalysts for ammonia synthesis was measured in a fixed bed plug flow system. 0.100 g of the Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 catalysts were loaded into a quartz tubular reactor with a diameter of 7 mm. Before ammonia synthesis, the catalysts were further treated in synthesis gas (H2/N2 = 3/1, 99.999 %, 60 mL min−1) at 400 ℃ for 3 h to reductively transform Ru cations to metallic Ru, and simultaneously decompose Cs-promoter. Ammonia reaction was performed in the temperature range of 300–400 ℃ under 0.1 MPa. The 1 mmol L−1 H2SO4 solution was used to trap the produced ammonia. The ammonia formation rate was calculated based on the decrease rate of the conductivity of the H2SO4 solution. During the activity tests, after the product gas was stabilized under each reaction condition for 20 min, it was introduced into a sulfuric acid solution for measurement. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of Ba5Ta4O15 support Fig. 1 a displays the XRD patterns of the Ta2O5 precursor and the as-obtained supports. It can be seen that the as-prepared support was composed of main phase crystalline Ba5Ta4O15 (PDF#72−0631), and tiny amount of unreacted Ta2O5 [38,39]. According to the Reference Intensity Ratio (RIR) method (RIR value: 9.14 for Ba5Ta4O15 and 15.37 for Ta2O5), the fraction of Ba5Ta4O15 was calculated as 93.2 wt% based on the intensity of XRD peaks of Ba5Ta4O15 and Ta2O5 at 30.8° and 22.9°. SEM observation shows that Ba5Ta4O15 support was nanosheets of 300−800 nm in lateral length and 10−20 nm in thickness, obviously different from the spherical particles of commercial product Ta2O5 with particle size of ∼100 nm (Fig. 1b and Figure S1). The nanosheet structure of Ba5Ta4O15 is expected to induce the epitaxial growth of strained flat Ru particles that allow the formation of more abundant B5 sites [34,35]. 3.2 Catalytic activity and stability of Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 Firstly, the factors influencing the ammonia synthesis rate over Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 were optimized including the molar ratios of Cs to Ru, and activation temperatures. As seen in Fig. 2 a, the addition of Cs can remarkably promote the catalytic performance of Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 catalyst for the ammonia synthesis. The ammonia synthesis rate was first improved with the increase of Cs content when the molar ratio of Cs to Ru was raised from 0 to 3, and then decreased when the molar ratio of Cs to Ru was further increased to 4. Therefore, the optimal molar ratio of Cs to Ru was 3. The ammonia synthesis rate over 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 was 5275 μmol g−1 cat h−1 at 400 ℃ and 0.1 MPa, 3.5 times that over Ru/Ba5Ta4O15. The results confirm the pivotal role of Cs promoters in ammonia synthesis over Ru/Ba5Ta4O15. The similar result was also obtained over Cs promoted Ru/Ta2O5 (Figure S2). But, the highest activity of 3Cs-Ru/Ta2O5 was only 762 μmol g−1 cat h−1 at 400 ℃ and 0.1 MPa, much lower than the 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15. Ba is considered to be a structural promoter that can provide more B5 active sites for ammonia synthesis [40]. In the 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 catalytic system, barium in the carrier could have a synergistic effect with Cs-promoter to enhance the activity of ammonia synthesis. Figure S3 shows the effect of activation temperature on the ammonia synthesis over 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15. The activation was conducted at different temperatures (300, 400 and 500 ℃) in synthesis gas flow (H2/N2 = 3, 60 mL min−1) for 3 h. It can be seen that the highest ammonia synthesis rate was observed with the 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 catalysts activated at 400 ℃. The promoter’s nitrate precursor cannot totally decompose at low activation temperatures (e.g., 300 ℃). However, the sinter of supported Ru particles would occur and their particle size could increase at higher activation temperatures such as 500 ℃. Therefore, too low or high activation temperatures are not conducive to the formation of high-performance 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 catalysts. As presented in Figure S4, Ru particles were evenly distributed on surface of Ba5Ta4O15 substrate. The average size of over 500 Ru grains is 1.97 nm (Figure S4b). The HRTEM image (Figure S4c) shows a lattice spacing of 0.206 nm and 0.285 nm corresponded to the (101) planes of Ru crystals and (110) planes of Ba5Ta4O15 crystals, respectively [41,42]. Figure S4d displays the TEM image of 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15. Due to cover by Cs-promoters at room temperature, much less Ru particles were observed. However, they presented the comparable sizes with those of Ru catalysts on Ba5Ta4O15. These Ru particles can be exposed to the reactants of N2 and H2 under ammonia synthesis conditions [31,34,43]. Stability of catalysts is the other important factor for practical application. Fig. 2b shows the duration of 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 and Cs-Ru/MgO as a comparison for ammonia synthesis. The ammonia synthesis rate of the Cs-Ru/MgO catalyst dropped from 4685 μmol g−1 cat h−1 by 22%–3638 μmol g−1 cat h−1 in 72 h. In comparison, the ammonia synthesis rate showed no obvious change during 72 h-reaction, suggesting 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 is stable for ammonia synthesis reaction. To gain an insight into evolution of 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15, the catalysts in three different stages (i.e., as-prepared (fresh), after 5-h activity tests (used) and after 72-h stability test (aged)) were analyzed by BET and XRD. BET specific surface area of fresh 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 was 8.5 m2 g−1, changed little (8.4 m2 g−1) after 5-h activity tests. However, the value was decreased slightly to 7.5 m2 g−1 after 72-h stability test possibly due to the sinter of 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 catalysts (Table S1). The XRD profiles show crystalline phase of CsNO3 can be found in the fresh catalysts. In comparison, no obvious phase of CsNO3 was detected in the used and aged catalysts, indicating that the Cs-promoters existed in amorphous or well-dispersed state after use for ammonia synthesis. In term of support stability, the used and aged 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 catalysts still can present the main diffraction lines of Ba5Ta4O15, indicating that the crystalline structure of the Ba5Ta4O15 substrate was well stable under reaction conditions (Figure S5). These results above show that 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 catalysts are of high catalytic performance and good stability for ammonia synthesis. The catalytic performance of 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 and other reported supported Ru catalysts was compared in terms of ammonia synthesis rate and turn over frequency (TOF) as presented in Table 1 . Because of the different Ru contents in these catalysts, the ammonia synthesis rate was compared based on the ammonia synthesis activity per gram of Ru. The 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 catalyst exhibited one of the highest catalytic activity for ammonia synthesis (263.7 mmol g−1 Ru h−1) at 400 ℃, which was higher than Ru/C12A7:e− (229.8 mmol g−1 Ru h−1) [20], and 3.7 times that of Ru/Pr2O3 [21]. At comparable lower reaction temperatures (340 ℃ or 350 ℃), ammonia synthesis rate of the 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 (2.0 wt% Ru) and 2Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 (3.8 wt% Ru) was 132.7 mmol g−1 Ru h−1 and 138.3 mmol g−1 Ru h−1, which was higher than Ru/BaO-CaH2 (105.0 mmol g−1 Ru h−1) [44], Cs-Ru/MgO (131.7 mmol g−1 Ru h−1) and Ru/CaH2 (74.0 mmol g−1 Ru h−1) [44]. The results indicate that 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 catalysts exhibit excellent catalytic activity for ammonia synthesis at 0.1 MPa. 3.3 Formation of oxygen vacancies The result of H2-TPR shows there was no reduction peak in the H2-TPR profile of Ta2O5 in the temperature range from 50 to 800 ℃ (Fig. 3 ), suggesting that Ta2O5 cannot be reduced in the temperature range. In comparison, reduction of Ba5Ta4O15 support occurred at 527 ℃ with the two reduction peaks at 644 ℃ and 800 ℃, indicating that the perovskite structure of Ba5Ta4O15 is conducive to its reduction. The two peaks at 644 ℃ and 800 ℃ is possibly due to reduction of Ta5+ to Ta4+, and further reduction to lower valence state (Ta3+). In order to confirm this consequence, Ta XPS and XRD of Ba5Ta4O15 pre-reduced by H2 at 650 °C and 800 °C were analyzed. Firstly, as seen in Figure S6a, XRD peaks of pre-reduced Ba5Ta4O15 had no obvious change after reduction at 650 ℃ and 800 ℃ as compared with the fresh Ba5Ta4O15. The result indicates that Ba5Ta4O15 had no remarkable change in bulk structure. Secondly, the binding energy of Ta (4d) was 229.7 eV for Ba5Ta4O15 (Figure S6b), and the surface content (atomic %) of O element was 72.11 % (Table S2). After the Ba5Ta4O15 reduced at 650 °C by H2, the binding energy of Ta (4d) shifted to 229.5 eV and the surface content (atomic %) of O element decreased to 70.25 %. The binding energy of Ta (4d) further shifted negatively to 229.3 eV, and surface content of O element further decreased to 68.57 % for reduced Ba5Ta4O15 at 800 °C by H2. These results indicate that Ta in Ba5Ta4O15 was reduced to lower valents (Ta4+/Ta3+). Combination of H2-TPR, XRD and XPS results, it is more rational to assign the two reduction peaks at 644 ℃ and 800 ℃ in profiles of H2-TPR to reduction of Ta5+ → Ta4+, and Ta4+ → Ta3+. For Ru/Ba5Ta4O15, one intense and broad reduction peak centered at 462 ℃, and one weak reduction peak occurred at 732 ℃ were observed. Through a quantitative estimation of the H2 consumption, it was found that H2 consumption (1702 μmol g−1) corresponding to the broad reduction peak greatly exceeded the theoretically calculated amount needed for reduction of RuO2 to Ru (396 μmol g−1). Therefore, we inferred that the excess H2 would react with surface or lattices oxygen of Ba5Ta4O15, which could further result in the formation of oxygen vacancies (OVs) [17,47]. The reduction curve of 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 catalyst clearly shows that the main peaks appeared at 168 ℃, 236 ℃ and 614 ℃. In Cs-promotes system, the CsNO3 did not decompose after reduction at 200 ℃ by H2. However, it can decompose in H2 at 400 ℃ as proved by disappearance of diffraction peaks of CsNO3. The result indicates that the broad peak at 168 ℃ may be attributed to the decomposition of CsNO3(Figure S7). The peak at 236 ℃ may be attributable to the reduction of Ta5+ to Ta4+, while the peak at 614 ℃ could be assigned to further reduction of Ta4+ to Ta3+ in 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 catalyst. The reduction temperatures for these peaks for 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 were lower than those of Ru/Ba5Ta4O15, indicating that the addition of Cs promoters facilitates the reduction of Ba5Ta4O15. The phenomenon may be related to the hydrogen spillover as previously reported in Ni-loaded Pr-doped ceria and Ru nanoparticles on CeO2 [48,49]. Fig. 4 shows XPS spectra of Ba5Ta4O15, used Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 and used 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15. As one can see in Fig. 4a, Ta 4f7/2 peak of Ba5Ta4O15 appeared at 25.7 eV. After loading Ru, the binding energy of Ta 4f7/2 peak of Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 shifted negatively to 25.5 eV. The presence of Cs-promoters further decreased the binding energy of Ta 4f7/2 peak of 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 to 25.2 eV. The results indicate that low-valent Ta species were formed in Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 and 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 during the ammonia synthesis reaction [50,51]. The results are consistent with the reduction of Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 and 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 as observed by H2-TPR in Fig. 3. As shown in Fig. 4b, O1s XPS of three catalyst samples can be decomposed into three peaks corresponding to lattice oxygen (Olat) at about 529 eV, oxygen atoms in the vicinity of oxygen vacancies (Ov) at about 530 eV and hydroxyl group (O−OH) at about 531 eV, respectively [52–54]. Through calculation of the relative area of the fitted sub peaks, the content of Ov species accounting for the total oxygen on surface of the three samples is listed in Table S3. The percentage of Ov species was calculated as only 4% for Ba5Ta4O15, and the value was increased to 24 % for Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 and 63 % for 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15. The results indicate that Ru and Cs loading can facilitate the reduction of Ba5Ta4O15 and formation of OVs, consistent with the results of H2-TPR (Fig. 3). Fig. 4c shows that the binding energy of Ru 3d5/2 for the used Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 catalysts was 279.9 eV (curve 2), which was 0.2 eV lower than that of Ru 3d5/2 (280.1 eV) in bulk Ru metal [55,56], hinting that electron density of Ru was increased due to the donation of mobile electrons in reduced Ba5Ta4O15 to Ru [16,17]. After loading Cs promoters, the binding energy of Ru 3d5/2 for the used 3Cs-2Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 was further decreased to 279.5 eV by 0.4 eV as compared to that for the used Ru/Ba5Ta4O15. The similar phenomenon was also found on Ru-Cs/MgO catalysts [57], which was attributed to the coating with an alkali metal-oxygen film [58,59]. By combining the results of H2-TPR and XPS, it is inferred that Ru catalysts and Cs promoters can facilitate the reduction of Ba5Ta4O15, and reduced Ba5Ta4O15 can further donate electrons to Ru [60], which can improve the activity of 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 catalysts for ammonia synthesis especially for activation of NN triple bonds in N2. The formation of OVs was further verified by electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra. As shown in Fig. 5 , there was no EPR signal of OVs in the fresh Ba5Ta4O15 and Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 catalysts. After 5-h activity test (400 ℃, H2/N2 = 3 with a flow rate of 60 mL min−1, 0.1 MPa), the used Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 showed a very weak EPR signal at a g value of 2.0035, confirming the presence of trace low-valent Ta-OVs in the Ba5Ta4O15. Comparably, the used 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 displayed a much stronger response at g = 2.0035, suggesting that more surface low-valent Ta species were generated in the used 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 due to the introduction of Cs-promoters. Moreover, there was a hyperfine splitting at g-factor of 2.0046 (The inset in Fig. 5). According to the reported literature, the g-factor at 2.0046 was attributed to electrons trapped in OVs [61]. The results agree well with the XPS observations that more decreased binding energy of Ta 4f7/2 peak and more content of OVs of 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 as compared with Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 (Fig. 4). 3.4 Role of oxygen vacancies To reveal the important role of OVs in ammonia synthesis by Ru/Ba5Ta4O15, a series of Ba5Ta4O15 supports with different contents of OVs were prepared through reduction by H2 at different temperatures (400, 450, 500, 550 and 600 ℃), confirmed by XRD and EPR, and further used to support Ru catalysts. As seen in Figure S8, the XRD patterns of the reduced Ba5Ta4O15 catalysts remained the same as the fresh one, indicating that the crystalline structure of the Ba5Ta4O15 samples was not changed or destroyed during the thermal-reduction process. However, the specific surface areas of the reduced Ba5Ta4O15 samples were decreased a little with the increase of calcination temperature (Table S4). Importantly, as one can see in Figure S9, the EPR signal of OVs was enhanced with the increase of reduction temperature, implying that more OVs were formed in the reduced Ba5Ta4O15 at higher reduction temperatures. Further, Ru was loaded on these reduced samples by the same impregnation method as that used for Ru/Ba5Ta4O15. Then the obtained Ru/reduced Ba5Ta4O15 catalysts were used for ammonia synthesis and the results are shown in Table 2 . The Ru content had no significant difference on the reduced Ba5Ta4O15 at different reduction temperatures. However, the dispersion of Ru catalysts on the reduced Ba5Ta4O15 could gradually decrease with increase of reduction temperatures due to the decreased specific surface areas of the reduced Ba5Ta4O15 as seen in Table 2 and Table S4. Of note, the catalytic activity of Ru/reduced Ba5Ta4O15 catalysts was remarkably improved as the reduction temperature was increased. For instance, when the reduction temperature was 600 ℃, ammonia synthesis rate by Ru/600Ba5Ta4O15 was 4380 μmol g−1 cat h−1, 2.9 and 2.1 times that by Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 and Ru/400Ba5Ta4O15. Correspondingly, TOF value of Ru/600Ba5Ta4O15 was 0.0182 s−1, 4.0 and 2.6 times that over Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 and Ru/400Ba5Ta4O15. Considering the nearly same Ru loading and the decreased dispersion of Ru on the reduced Ba5Ta4O15, we infer that the dramatic enhancement of the catalytic activity of Ru/reduced Ba5Ta4O15 catalysts was ascribed to the presence of OVs in the support of reduced Ba5Ta4O15. After ammonia synthesis, OVs still existed in Ru/reduced Ba5Ta4O15 catalysts (Figure S10). Li et al. found that the OVs of BiOBr and BiOCl nanosheets could adsorb N2 and further suggested electrons exchange and transfer mainly occurred between N2 and OVs [32,33]. The back transfer of charges from OVs in reduced Ba5Ta4O15 to the adsorbed N2 could facilitate the cleavage of NN triple bond on Ru catalysts and further improve the catalytic activity of ammonia synthesis. 3.5 Adsorption and dissociation of N2 To further prove the high catalytic performance of Ru base catalysts, the adsorbed state of N2 on the Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 and 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 catalysts were researched using in situ FTIR spectroscopy. As seen in Fig. 6 , one peak appeared at 2035 cm−1 for 14N2 adsorbed on Ru/Ba5Ta4O15. In order to confirm whether the peak was the absorbed N2 on the surface of Ru, the 15N2 isotope experiments were conducted. In the spectrum of 15N2 adsorbed on Ru/Ba5Ta4O15, the peak shifted to 1968 cm−1 by 67 cm−1 compared to that for 14N2 adsorbed on Ru/Ba5Ta4O15. Based on the isotope effect, the NN stretching peak of the N2 adsorbed on Ru should be at 1966 cm−1 (2035×(14/15)1/2 cm−1), consistent with the observed value (1968 cm−1). The results indicate that the peak at 2035 cm−1 belonged to the NN stretching peak of the N2 adsorbed on Ru of Ru/Ba5Ta4O15. Moreover, it was lower than those on Ru/Al2O3 (2214 cm−1) [62], Ru/MgO (2168 cm−1) [62], Ru/Pr2O3 (2178 cm−1) [21], and Ru/C12A7:e− (2124 cm−1) [20]. These results indicate that the NN bond of N2 was weakened more significantly over Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 as compared with Ru particles on the other supports. After loading Cs as a promoter, the NN stretching peak of chemisorbed N2 shifted to lower frequency. The peak attributed to NN stretching peak of the 14N2 adsorbed shifted to 1966 cm−1 for 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15, and red-shifted by 63 cm−1 to 1903 cm−1 for that for the 15N2 adsorbed on Ru surface in the 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 system. The observed value was close to the calculated value based on the isotope effect (1966 cm−1×(14/15)1/2 = 1899 cm−1). The result indicates that the sharp band at 1966 cm−1 was attributed to N2 absorbed on Ru surface in the 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 system. Thus, the addition of Cs further enhanced weakness of the NN bond. To further confirm the NH3 formation, the reduced Ba5Ta4O15 was used for ammonia synthesis. When the reaction temperature was increased from 600 ℃ and 700 ℃ to 800 ℃ and 900 ℃, the conductivity of the H2SO4 solution declined more obviously, suggesting that NH3 formation can happen on Ba5Ta4O15 after reduction at higher temperatures (Figure S11). It has been previously reported the BaTiO2.5H0.5 without loading of precious metals could activate N2 and H2 to form ammonia, where hydride played a key role in catalytic synthesis of ammonia via Mars van Krevelen mechanism [63]. Recently, it has been also reported that BaCeO3-xNyHz catalyst can catalyze the synthesis of ammonia without loading any metal [64]. In our experiment, the Ba5Ta4O15 can form OVs after reduced by H2. Ru particles can increase the reduction of Ba5Ta4O15 through hydrogen spillover, and loading Cs-promoter further increased the degree of reduction of Ba5Ta4O15, which promote the ammonia synthesis activity of Ba5Ta4O15. The conclusion can be further confirmed by XPS spectra of N1s as seen in Figure S12. XPS spectra of N1s were observed on the used Ba5Ta4O15 reduced at 600 ℃, while no signal of N1s was detected on the used 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 and Ru/Ba5Ta4O15. The NH3 desorption on the 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15, Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 and Ba5Ta4O15 was further investigated by NH3-TPD analysis. Figure S13 presents there were two main NH3 desorption peaks on the NH3-TPD of all the three catalysts, including a small peak at 161 ℃ and a large peak at higher temperature (700–900 ℃), which were attributed to weak adsorption and strong adsorption of ammonia, respectively. The temperature for NH3 desorption was located at 900 ℃ for Ba5Ta4O15, and the value was decreased to about 800 and 700 ℃ corresponding to Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 and 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15. The result indicates that loading Ru and Cs can facilitate the NH3 desorption on 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15. Combined results of H2-TPR, XPS, EPR, and in situ FTIR fully demonstrate that ammonia synthesis can be highly efficiently conducted on Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15, OVs in Ba5Ta4O15 facilitate the ammonia synthesis, and the loading of Cs and Ru enhances the formation and desorption of NH3. 3.6 Kinetic analysis In order to further understand the reaction mechanism for ammonia synthesis over 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15, the kinetic experiments were conducted (Fig. 7 and Table S5). The N2 reaction order of 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 was 0.47, lower than that of Cs-Ru/MgO (0.87) [27], Ru/MgO (0.88) [27], Ru/BaTiO2.5H0.5 (0.88) [60], and Ru/Ca2N:e− (0.53) [23], and comparable with Ru/C12A7:e− (0.46) [20], indicating that the dissociation of N2 can be facilely and efficiently conducted and was not the rate-limiting step of ammonia synthesis over 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15. In the electride support, the rate-limiting step of ammonia synthesis is not dissociation of the NN triple bond, but the formation and desorption of NHx species [65,66]. According to the discussion above, the addition of Cs promoted the reduction of Ba5Ta4O15 with the generation of more OVs which could capture electrons, making 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 an electronic catalyst. The OVs and Cs-promoter can donate electrons to Ru together to facilitate the dissociation of nitrogen. Hydrogen poisoning at high hydrogen partial pressure is another obstacle to the application of Ru-based catalysts in industrial ammonia synthesis. The H2 reaction order of 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 was 1.01 as shown in Fig. 7, which was higher than that of the other Ru catalysts on various supports (Table S5). In general, the adsorption and dissociation of H2 on Ru surface take place more easily than that of N2 molecules because bond energy of the NN bond in N2 is 945 kJ mol−1, much higher that of the HH bond in H2 (436 kJ mol−1) [20,67]. Adsorption of excess hydrogen atoms on Ru catalysts reduces active sites on Ru surface for dissociation of N2, hindering the dissociation of N2 and further inhibiting the catalytic activity of ammonia synthesis [13]. The positive H2 reaction order observed with 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 means that the catalyst is not poisoned by hydrogen. Firstly, H2 adsorbed and dissociated on the surface of Ru to become the adsorbed H atoms. The H adatoms on Ru surface could spill over into the support of Ba5Ta4O15, resulting in the reduction of Ba5Ta4O15 and decrease of surface adsorbed H atoms coverage on Ru surface. Secondly, the reduction of H adatoms on the Ru surface means that there were more active sites on the Ru surface for the adsorption and dissociation of N2. Moreover, the reduced Ba5Ta4O15 could donate the electrons to Ru to further enhance the adsorption and dissociation of N2 and increase the amount of N adatoms on Ru surface. Finally, the reaction of N adatoms and adsorbed H adatoms was further accelerated to form the NHx in kinetics. In comparison, the reaction order of NH3 for 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 was -1.85, which was lower than those reported for other catalysts (Table S5), suggesting that desorption of NHx species can affect the activity of ammonia synthesis over 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15. The result is consistent with the higher apparent activation energy of 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 (2.0 wt% Ru) (77 kJ mol−1) and 2Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 (3.8 wt% Ru) (68 kJ mol−1) than the Ru/C12A7:e- (49 kJ mol-1) and Ru/BaO-CaH2 (41 kJ mol-1) [20,44] (Table 1). These kinetic results indicate that the formation and desorption of NHx species are the rate-limiting step of ammonia synthesis over 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15. 3.7 Mechanism of ammonia synthesis on 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 catalyst According to the results above, the ammonia synthesis mechanism on Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 is proposed (Scheme 1 ). The Ru particles were loaded on Ba5Ta4O15 via impregnation method and CsNO3 was further loaded by physical grinding. Under the reaction conditions for ammonia synthesis (flow rate 60 mL min−1, H2/N2 3:1), OVs can be formed on surface of the perovskite-type Ba5Ta4O15 through the reduction by H2. Meanwhile, Ba5Ta4O15 transformed to Ba5Ta4O15-xHx. The presence of OVs enhanced the activation and dissociation of N2 on Ba5Ta4O15 by donating electrons. The activation of N2 and formation of ammonia can be realized on reduced Ba5Ta4O15 with OVs even without the loading of Ru catalysts and Cs promoters. The Ru particles further enhanced the reduction of Ba5Ta4O15 by hydrogen spillover. Cs-promoters facilitated the formation of more OVs in Ba5Ta4O15 and further promoted electrons donating to Ru, finally significantly improving the dissociation of N2 molecules. Moreover, the positive H2 reaction order observed with 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 indicates that the catalyst is not poisoned by hydrogen due to the ability of support Ba5Ta4O15 to accept excess H2 as a “reservoir” of active hydrogen. The positive N2 reaction order indicates that activation and dissociation of triple bond of N2 is not the rate-limiting step of ammonia synthesis in 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 catalyst. Finally, the produced NH3 can be efficiently desorbed from surface of 3Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 under the promotion effect of loaded Ru and Cs. 4 Conclusion In summary, we demonstrate that the perovskite-type Ba5Ta4O15 is an excellent support of Ru-based catalyst for ammonia synthesis. The Cs co-catalyzed Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 (Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15) catalyst exhibits high activity and stability for ammonia synthesis under mild reaction conditions (Reactant gas, H2/N2 = 3 with a flow rate of 60 mL min−1; pressure, 0.1 MPa). Reaction mechanism investigation suggests that oxygen vacancies (OVs) in support of Ba5Ta4O15 play a pivotal role in enhanced ammonia synthesis over Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 catalysts. Through regulation of OVs on Ba5Ta4O15 by changing the reduction temperatures, it has been confirmed that the presence of OVs in Ba5Ta4O15 is the key to dissociation of N2 on Ba5Ta4O15 based catalysts. The activation of N2 and formation of ammonia can be directly realized on the Ba5Ta4O15 with OVs. Ru catalyst and Cs-promoter can facilitate the reduction of Ba5Ta4O15 and formation of more OVs. Meanwhile, the formed OVs in Ba5Ta4O15 can behave as an electron donor to increase the electron density of Ru species, thus promoting ammonia synthesis. This work not only clarifies the important role of OVs in support Ba5Ta4O15 in promoted activation of N2 and ammonia synthesis, but also provides a high-performance and stability ammonia synthesis catalyst of Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15. coredata.dc:description: Efficient ammonia synthesis is a significant but challenging target. Herein, the perovskite Ba5Ta4O15 nanosheets were prepared as a support to rationally construct Cs modified Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 (Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15) for this end. The Cs-Ru/Ba5Ta4O15 catalyst exhibits high catalytic activity and stability in 72 h ammonia synthesis reaction process at 400 ℃ and 0.1 MPa. Characterizations by various physicochemical techniques reveal that Ba5Ta4O15 can be reduced, resulting in formation of oxygen vacancies (OVs) under reaction conditions. The presence of OVs in Ba5Ta4O15 significantly enhances the ammonia synthesis of the Ru based catalyst. The activation of N2 and formation of NH3 can be realized on Ba5Ta4O15 with OVs even without Ru metals. Moreover, the kinetic experiments indicate that hydrogen poisoning is greatly inhibited through promotion of hydrogen spillover from Ru to support of Ba5Ta4O15. Therefore, Ba5Ta4O15 is expected to be a promising support of Ru based ammonia synthesis catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Cs-Promoted ruthenium catalyst supported on Ba5Ta4O15 with abundant oxygen vacancies for ammonia synthesis
